ygData.subject: Re: HyperNEAT Activation Functions
ygData.msgSnippet: Colin, there really has never been a definitive study as far as I know on how different sets of activation functions affect performance.  I am sure it would be

Colin, there really has never been a definitive study as far as I know on h=
ow different sets of activation functions affect performance.  I am sure it=
 would be domain-dependent.  It is possible that some functions with abrupt=
 changes could complement their more gradual counterparts, or it could turn=
 out disruptive for some reason.  It's hard to say.  But my feeling is that=
 in general it is not a critical kind of decision, though it might affect p=
erformance to some extent.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <=
colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
> 2009/7/1 Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>:
> >
>=
 > Colin, I don't think there is any agreed standard set. However, I genera=
lly
> > recommend not having more than one of each kind.
> 
> Understood. S=
tart with a minimal set and maybe introduce others at a
> later time if the=
y show promise. E.g. I wonder about functions with
> abrupt changes in rate=
 of change, e.g. abs and square, and whether
> they are complementary or su=
bstitutes for functions with a similar
> overall profile but with smoother =
curves, e.g. gaussian and sine.
> 
> > I also agree that something like an =
unbounded linear function can have
> > unintended consequences.
> >
> > My =
guess is that even sigmoids and Gaussians alone can work well, although
> >=
 it's just a hunch.
> >
> 
> Thanks.
>
